source.6fad14ba:
The Poisson distribution is the case of a binomial distribution, when the number of tests n is sufficiently large, and the probability p of event A is small ().

The Poisson distribution is also called the distribution of rare events. For example, the birth of three or four twins in a year, the same distribution law has the number of atoms of a radioactive substance decayed per unit time, etc.
source.384b5651: A random variable is called a variable that can take one or another value depending on various circumstances, and a random variable is called continuous if it can take any value from any limited or unlimited range. For a continuous random variable, it is impossible to indicate all possible values, therefore, indicate the intervals of these values that are associated with certain probabilities.
source.ff80a16b: Examples of continuous random variables include: diameter of the part to be machined to a given size, human height, projectile range, etc. Examples of discrete random variables with a finite number of values can be the number of children born during the day in the village, the number of bus passengers, and the number of passengers transported by the London Underground per day, etc.
source.7b10900c: In probability theory and statistics, the Bernoulli distribution, named after Swiss mathematician Jacob Bernoulli, is the discrete probability distribution of a random variable which takes the value 1 with probability p and the value 0 with probability q = 1 - p. Less formally, it can be thought of as a model for the set of possible outcomes of any single experiment that asks a yes–no question. Such questions lead to outcomes that are boolean-valued: a single bit whose value is success/yes/true/one with probability p and failure/no/false/zero with probability q. It can be used to represent a (possibly biased) coin toss where 1 and 0 would represent "heads" and "tails", respectively, and p would be the probability of the coin landing on heads or tails, respectively. In particular, unfair coins would have: $$ { p\neq 1/2} $$
source.2b8673de: The exponential distribution models the time between two successive occurrences of the event, and the parameter λ describes the average number of occurrences of the event per unit time. Usually using this law they describe: the duration of customer service, the life time of the equipment to failure, the time interval between breakdowns, etc.
source.93ab7711:
# Distribution Guide
Distributions (or generalized functions) are objects that generalize the classical notion of functions in mathematical analysis. Distributions make it possible to differentiate functions whose derivatives do not exist in the classical sense. In particular, any locally integrable function has a distributional derivative. Distributions are widely used in the theory of partial differential equations, where it may be easier to establish the existence of distributional solutions than classical solutions, or appropriate classical solutions may not exist. Distributions are also important in physics and engineering where many problems naturally lead to differential equations whose solutions or initial conditions are distributions, such as the Dirac delta function.
source.d8219334: Metro trains run regularly at intervals of 2 (min.). The passenger leaves the platform at a random moment in time, in no way connected with the train schedule. The random variable T - the time during which he will have to wait for the train, has a uniform distribution.
source.2f504fc3: Modeling of physical or other complex processes: production processes, website behavior, etc.
source.edeb7625: Examples of random variables distributed according to the normal law are human growth, the mass of fish caught in one species. Normality of distribution means the following: there are values of human growth, mass of fish of one species, which are intuitively perceived as “normal” (but essentially averaged), and they are found in a rather large sample much more often than those differing in larger or smaller side.
